awd_abstract_narration:
Microrobots less than a millimeter on a side have many potential biomedical applications, including cell manipulation, endoscopy, microorganism studies, targeted drug delivery, cancer therapy, and numerous medical procedures. This project addresses the problem of orienting a free-floating microrobot in three dimensions -- that is, the problem of simultaneously pointing each of three mutually perpendicular edges of the robot in a specified direction. In traditional applications such as spacecraft this is done, for example, using spinning wheels mounted on the body. However traditional approaches are currently infeasible on the submillimeter length scale. This project will demonstrate microrobots capable of precise orientation control using a novel arrangement of vibrating mass actuators. Such microrobots have the potential to transform invasive medical procedures such as endoscopy, micofabrication, and targeted drug delivery. 

The primary aim of this project is to demonstrate 3-axis orientation control of a microrobot with onboard actuation. This multidisciplinary project requires advances in noncommutative orientation control theory and microfabrication. Noncommutative orientation control is a new approach to orientation control that takes advantage of the noncommutative property of rigid-body rotations. The control technique generates noncommutative rotations using moving-mass actuators to generate a rapid sequence of positive and negative torques about 2 of the body-fixed orthogonal axes. This sequence causes zero net rotation about those 2 body-fixed axes, while causing a nonzero net rotation about the remaining orthogonal axis. Unlike traditional attitude control technology such as reactions wheels and control moment gyros, noncommutative orientation control can be implemented at the microscale. This project also aims to advance the state-of-the-art in microfabrication by combining lithography-based microfabrication and micro-origami self-assembly.

Title:

Orientation Control of Microrobots

Outcomes:

The objective of this project was to develop on-board orientation control techniques for microrobots. Although microrobotics is a rapidly developing field, the vast majority of potential applications remain at the conceptual stage because of the fundamental challenges associated with onboard power and actuation. In particular, orientation control with onboard actuation is a significant challenge because conventional macro-scale actuation systems are difficult to implement at microscales.  

This project developed a new microscale orientation control approach that takes advantage of the noncommutative property of rigid-body rotations. The control technique generates noncommutative rotations using moving-mass actuators to generate a rapid sequence of positive and negative rotations about two of the body-fixed orthogonal axes. This sequence causes zero net rotation about those two body-fixed axes, while causing a nonzero net rotation about the remaining orthogonal axis. Unlike traditional attitude control technologies such as reactions wheels and control moment gyros, noncommutative orientation control can be implemented at the microscale with shape-change actuation systems. Examples of shape-change actuation systems include moving masses, vibrating beams, and oscillating wheels.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes: One significant contribution of this project was the development of novel attitude control techniques for shape-change actuation systems. These algorithms use sinusoidal controls to achieve set-point tracking and command following. We also developed specializations of these control techniques to accommodate practical restrictions on actuation frequency and sampling rate. Finally, we developed algorithms for multiagent systems, where each agent uses a shape-change attitude actuation system. The algorithms achieve orientation consensus for the case where each agent uses orientation feedback of its neighbor agents.

Another contribution of this work is experimental demonstration of orientation control using shape-change actuation at the macroscale. We constructed a macroscale experimental testbed to demonstrate both open-loop and closed-loop attitude control. The experiments successfully demonstrated the new attitude control techniques for setpoint tracking.

We also developed a novel design and microfabrication techniques for a microscale robot with an on-board shape-change attitude actuation system. The actuation system consists of magnetically responsive microbeam actuators, which vibrate under an externally applied oscillatory magnetic field. The microbeam actuators are designed with different resonant frequencies to enable noncommuative rotations.  The microbeam actuator design relies on a new microfabrication methods that we developed to significantly increase the efficiency of ferromagnetic microbeam actuators. We fabricated multiple microbots and demonstrated the actuation concept with one-dimensional open-loop experiments. 

Broader Impacts Outcomes:

The fundamental methods and techniques that we developed have broad application and benefit to society. The application area of medical microrobotics has the potential to transform invasive medical procedures. Microrobots that are capable of precise orientation control have the potential to transform invasive medical procedures such as endoscopy, micofabrication, and targeted drug delivery. Such robots could also be used for a variety of health monitoring objectives. When the size of these microrobots decreases to 10 μm, they will be small enough to access all parts of the vascular system, and such microrobots could be placed nearly anywhere in the human body. The control theory and experimental methods that were developed in this work also have application to other attitude control technologies, such as small air vehicles, water vehicles, or space satellites.

This project created opportunities for university students to contribute to the fields of dynamic systems and control and microrobotics. This project provided training for 5 graduate students. This project also promoted participation, particularly from underrepresented groups, in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. Specifically, one female graduate student participated in this project.
